elements.content: Decoding the principles of cluster-based framework assembly at the molecular level remains a persistent challenge. Herein, we isolated and characterized a novel water-stable three-dimensional (3D) metal–organic open framework [Cl@Ag14(cPrCC)10Cl2·(p-TOS)·1/3H2O] n (SD/Ag14, cPrCCH = cyclopropylacetylene; p-TOS = p-toluenesulfonate), which contains a chloride-templated Ag14 cluster as building block. For SD/Ag14, one chloride acts as the template to shape the Ag14 cluster and the other bridges the clusters to a 3D pcu-h open framework. As revealed by high resolution electrospray mass spectrometry (HRESI-MS), the Ag12–Ag14 species are potential cluster-based intermediates to the 3D pcu-h framework, which authenticates a preconceived idea that the 3D framework is hierarchically assembled from the silver clusters as observed in solid state. Interestingly, SD/Ag14 can be used effectively to remove the environmental pollutant Cr2O7 2– from wastewater through anion exchange in a single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SC–SC) transformation fashion. Furthermore, SD/Ag14 exhibits excellent antibacterial activity against Staphylococcus aureus, thus making it a potential antibacterial agent.

Furthermore, SD/Ag14 exhibits excellent antibacterial activity against Staphylococcus aureus, thus making it a potential antibacterial agent.

elements.content: The incessant demands for open framework materials in the fields of absorption, catalysis, filtering and ion exchange have inspired wide interest in synthesizing crystalline frameworks of novel chemical compositions with functional groups to generate selectivity and structural characteristic-dependent functions. The most famous open framework materials are inorganic aluminosilicates and aluminophosphates with their excellent thermal stability and good optical transparency. In parallel with the advances made for such purely inorganic open frameworks, another kind of porous materials called metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), made from metal ions or clusters and bridging organic ligands, promoted this field to higher level through highly tunable structures and properties. In the synthesis of MOFs, metal clusters are often observed as the secondary building blocks in extended nets. However, silver cluster based 3D open frameworks are still rare. Silver clusters usually contains more than ten metals in one unit and exhibit some special geometrical features such as Platonic or Archimedean solids. Their fascinating argentophilic interactions not only contribute to the formation of aggregation of silver atoms but also have important influences on the luminescence properties. The Zang group reported a Ag31 cluster based a 2D layer formed through the linkage of NO3 –. Our group has long been pursuing the synthesis of novel silver clusters and related extended frameworks, and very recently, we isolated the first 3D 2-fold interpenetrated dia open framework based on a sulfate-templated Ag22 cluster. Although there are some examples, how they are built from solution is still difficult to understand. This problem is further exacerbated for cluster-based assembly where building blocks could be identified from single crystal X-ray diffraction results but may not genuinely exist in solution. The possible solution depends on electrospray mass spectrometry that can identify the stable species in solution before final crystallization to the solid state.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The incessant demands for open framework materials in the fields of absorption, catalysis, filtering and ion exchange have inspired wide interest in synthesizing crystalline frameworks of novel chemical compositions with functional groups to generate selectivity and structural characteristic-dependent functions. The most famous open framework materials are inorganic aluminosilicates and aluminophosphates with their excellent thermal stability and good optical transparency. In parallel with the advances made for such purely inorganic open frameworks, another kind of porous materials called metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), made from metal ions or clusters and bridging organic ligands, promoted this field to higher level through highly tunable structures and properties. In the synthesis of MOFs, metal clusters are often observed as the secondary building blocks in extended nets. However, silver cluster based 3D open frameworks are still rare. Silver clusters usually contains more than ten metals in one unit and exhibit some special geometrical features such as Platonic or Archimedean solids. Their fascinating argentophilic interactions not only contribute to the formation of aggregation of silver atoms but also have important influences on the luminescence properties. The Zang group reported a Ag31 cluster based a 2D layer formed through the linkage of NO3 -. Our group has long been pursuing the synthesis of novel silver clusters and related extended frameworks, and very recently, we isolated the first 3D 2-fold interpenetrated dia open framework based on a sulfate-templated Ag22 cluster. Although there are some examples, how they are built from solution is still difficult to understand. This problem is further exacerbated for cluster-based assembly where building blocks could be identified from single crystal X-ray diffraction results but may not genuinely exist in solution. The possible solution depends on  electrospray mass spectrometry that can identify the stable species in solution before final crystallization to the solid state.

elements.content: In addition, the ligands stabilizing these clusters have unique properties. For example, alkynyl ligands have strong binding affinity to the Ag atom through σ and π bonding and many extended silver–alkynyl networks including 1D chains, tapes, 2D layers, and 3D networks have been reported by Mak and co-workers. When an anion was introduced as templates, silver–alkynyl discrete clusters could also be synthesized. Among numerous silver–alkynyl networks, only a few cases are 3D open frameworks, for example, 2Ag2C4·2AgF·6AgNO3·H2O. Moreover, no distinguishable cluster building blocks could be found in their solid state structures, which hinders our understanding of the cluster-based assembly process.
elements.clean_text: In addition, the ligands stabilizing these clusters have unique properties. For example, alkynyl ligands have strong binding affinity to the Ag atom through σ and π bonding and many extended silver-alkynyl networks including 1D chains, tapes, 2D layers, and 3D networks have been reported by Mak and co-workers. When an anion was introduced as templates, silver-alkynyl discrete clusters could also be synthesized. Among numerous silver-alkynyl networks, only a few cases are 3D open frameworks, for example, 2Ag2C4⋅2AgF⋅6AgNO3⋅H2O. Moreover, no distinguishable cluster building blocks could be found in their solid state structures, which hinders our understanding of the cluster-based assembly process.

elements.content: Using the aforementioned knowledge, herein we isolated and characterized a novel water-stable three-dimensional (3D) metal–organic open framework, [Cl@Ag14(cPrCC)10Cl2·(p-TOS)·1/3H2O] n (SD/Ag14, cPrCCH = cyclopropylacetylene; p-TOS = p-toluenesulfonate), which contains a chloride-templated tetradecanuclear silver cluster as building block. For SD/Ag14, the chloride acts not only as template to shape the tetradecanuclear silver cluster from the interior but also bridges the cluster to an extended 3D pcu-h open framework. High-resolution electrospray mass spectrometry (HRESI-MS) was also used to study the solution behaviors as well as their cluster-based assembly process in solution. SD/Ag14 also adsorbs the environmental pollutant Cr2O7 2– through anion exchange in a single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SC–SC) fashion.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of [cPrCCAg] n  

Ethynylcyclopropane (24 mmol, 2 mL) in ethanol (15 mL) was added to Ag2O (13 mmol, 3 g) in ammonia solution (60 mL). The mixture was stirred for 1 h, and the white precipitate (3.9 g, 93.3%) was collected by sucking filtration, then washed with EtOH and Et2O.

elements.content: [cPrCCAg] n (0.1 mmol, 17.4 mg), NaCl (0.11 mmol, 6.5 mg), and p-TOSAg (0.1 mmol, 27.9 mg) were dissolved in distilled EtOH (5 mL) in the presence of 10 μL of tetramethylethylenediamine (TMEDA); the resulting solution was treated by sonication for 20 min at room temperature to give a turbid solution, which was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and kept at 60 °C for 1200 min and then slowly cooled to room temperature (). The colorless filtrate was left to stand in the dark at room temperature. After one month, colorless crystals were deposited with a yield of 25%. When p-TOSAg was replaced by p-TOSH in the presence of 40 μL of TMEDA, colorless crystals of SD/Ag14 were obtained with an optimized yield of 50% after 1 week. Anal. for C171H173Ag42Cl9S3O10 (SD/Ag14), calcd (found): C, 28.00 (28.02); H, 2.38 (2.37) %. IR: 3668 (w), 2973 (s), 2903 (s), 1398 (m), 1240 (w), 1072 (s), 887 (w) cm–1. The colorless crystals of SD/Ag14 were immersed in an aqueous solution of K2Cr2O7 (0.08 mg mL–1) for 48 h to give orange crystals of SD/Ag16.

Synthesis of SD/Ag14 and SD/Ag16

The colorless filtrate was left to stand in the dark at room temperature. After one month, colorless crystals were deposited with a yield of 25%. When p-TOSAg was replaced by p-TOSH in the presence of 40 μL of TMEDA, colorless crystals of SD/Ag14 were obtained with an optimized yield of 50% after 1 week. Anal. for C171H173Ag42Cl9S3O10 (SD/Ag14), calcd (found): C, 28.00 (28.02); H, 2.38 (2.37) %. IR: 3668 (w), 2973 (s), 2903 (s), 1398 (m), 1240 (w), 1072 (s), 887 (w) cm-1. The colorless crystals of SD/Ag14 were immersed in an aqueous solution of K2Cr2O7 (0.08 mg mL-1) for 48 h to give orange crystals of SD/Ag16.

elements.content: The compound SD/Ag15 was prepared by solvothermal reaction as follows: [cPrCCAg] n (0.1 mmol, 17.4 mg), p-TOSAg (0.1 mmol, 27.9 mg), and CH3(CH2)3OH (5 mL) were mixed together and then sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and kept at 60 °C for 1200 min. After cooling to room temperature, the colorless crystals were collected in 40% yield. Anal. for C112H136Ag16S8O28 (SD/Ag15), calcd (found): C, 34.38 (34.35); H, 2.35 (2.36) %. IR: 3387 (w), 2989 (w), 2003 (m), 1640 (w), 1595­(w), 1487 (w), 1161 (s), 1116 (s), 1016 (s), 944 (m), 816 (m), 681 (m), 572 (s) cm–1.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of SD/Ag15 

The compound SD/Ag15 was prepared by solvothermal reaction as follows: [cPrCCAg] n  (0.1 mmol, 17.4 mg), p-TOSAg (0.1 mmol, 27.9 mg), and CH3(CH2)3OH (5 mL) were mixed together and then sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and kept at 60 °C for 1200 min. After cooling to room temperature, the colorless crystals were collected in 40% yield. Anal. for C112H136Ag16S8O28 (SD/Ag15), calcd (found): C, 34.38 (34.35); H, 2.35 (2.36) %. IR: 3387 (w), 2989 (w), 2003 (m), 1640 (w), 1595(w), 1487 (w), 1161 (s), 1116 (s), 1016 (s), 944 (m), 816 (m), 681 (m), 572 (s) cm-1.

elements.content: The synthesis of SD/Ag14, Supporting Information (SI), must start from [cPrCCAg] n and additional portion of silver salt, whereas the direct mixing of cPrCCH and the silver salt does not give any crystalline product. Reaction of [cPrCCAg] n and silver salt instantly produce a voluminous precipitate under stirring or ultrasound treatment. To address this issue, solvothermal treatment at relatively low temperature (∼60 °C) dissolves most of the precipitate. The filtrates slowly evaporated at room temperature to produce tiny crystals in a yield of 15%. The solvent for the synthesis of SD/Ag14 is a mixture of ethanol and CH2Cl2. In the absence of only ethanol, we do not get any crystalline products apart from an unidentified precipitate. The Cl– should be from the decomposition of CH2Cl2, which is very similar to the example of snowman-like [Cl@Ag19] cluster, where the Cl– was believed to be originated from the CHCl3 solvent. We, alternatively, used distilled ethanol to perform the reaction in the presence of NaCl and higher yield of SD/Ag14 (>25%) could be achieved, which also supported the Cl– template effect in the assembly of such silver cluster-based open framework. If running the reaction in other nonchlorinated solvents such as CH3(CH2)3OH, the one-dimensional silver-alkynyl coordination polymer, [Ag16(cPrCC)8(p-TOS)8(CH3(CH2)3OH)2·2­(CH3(CH2)3OH)] n (SD/Ag15) was obtained.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis Discussions

The synthesis of SD/Ag14, Supporting Information (SI), must start from [cPrCCAg] n  and additional portion of silver salt, whereas the direct mixing of cPrCCH and the silver salt does not give any crystalline product. Reaction of [cPrCCAg] n  and silver salt instantly produce a voluminous precipitate under stirring or ultrasound treatment. To address this issue, solvothermal treatment at relatively low temperature (~60 °C) dissolves most of the precipitate. The filtrates slowly evaporated at room temperature to produce tiny crystals in a yield of 15%. The solvent for the synthesis of SD/Ag14 is a mixture of ethanol and CH2Cl2. In the absence of only ethanol, we do not get any crystalline products apart from an unidentified precipitate. The Cl- should be from the decomposition of CH2Cl2, which is very similar to the example of snowman-like [Cl@Ag19] cluster, where the Cl- was believed to be originated from the CHCl3 solvent. We, alternatively, used distilled ethanol to perform the reaction in the presence of NaCl and higher yield of SD/Ag14 (>25%) could be achieved, which also supported the Cl- template effect in the assembly of such silver cluster-based open framework. If running the reaction in other nonchlorinated solvents such as CH3(CH2)3OH, the one-dimensional silver-alkynyl coordination polymer, [Ag16(cPrCC)8(p-TOS)8(CH3(CH2)3OH)2⋅2(CH3(CH2)3OH)] n  (SD/Ag15) was obtained.

elements.content: The solid state structure of SD/Ag14 was determined from single crystal X-ray diffraction where the asymmetric unit contains 14 Ag atoms, 10 cPrCC–, and 3 Cl–, as well as one p-TOS and 1/3 water guest molecule. Compound SD/Ag14 crystallizes in the trigonal R3̅ space group and is organized as a 3D open framework. As shown in a, the subunit in the 3D open framework is a chloride-templated Ag14 cluster with ten cPrCC– ligands and two bridging Cl– coordinated on the exterior. The ball-shaped Cl– resides within the cluster with Ag–Cl distances in the range 2.77–3.15 Å, giving a μ6-binding mode. Two external Cl– ions adopt μ3-mode to cap the surface of the Ag14 cluster (Ag–Cl, 2.58–3.00 Å). The 10 cPrCC– ligands exhibit different coordination modes with mixed σ- and π-type bonding; 3 in μ4-ησ 1:ηπ 1:ηπ 1:ηπ 2; 5 in μ3-ησ 1:ησ 1:ηπ 2; 1 in μ3-ησ 1:ησ 1:ησ 1; 1 in μ3-ησ 1:ηπ 1:ηπ. The Ag–C distances range from 2.07 to 2.48 Å. The overall silver shell is also reinforced by Ag···Ag interactions ranging from 2.86 to 3.42 Å. These argentophilic interactions were also evidenced by the low-frequency bands in the solid-state Raman spectrum taken with laser excitation of λex = 632.8 nm (Figure S1). A moderate sharp peak located at 69.2 cm–1 was observed, which corresponds to the stretching vibration of the Ag···Ag bonds. The characteristic band for the CC stretching vibration was observed at ca. 2010 cm–1.
elements.clean_text:
Structures of SD/Ag14 and SD/Ag15 

The solid state structure of SD/Ag14 was determined from single crystal X-ray diffraction where the asymmetric unit contains 14 Ag atoms, 10 cPrCC-, and 3 Cl-, as well as one p-TOS and 1/3 water guest molecule. Compound SD/Ag14 crystallizes in the trigonal R3̅ space group and is organized as a 3D open framework. As shown in a, the subunit in the 3D open framework is a chloride-templated Ag14 cluster with ten cPrCC- ligands and two bridging Cl- coordinated on the exterior. The ball-shaped Cl- resides within the cluster with Ag-Cl distances in the range 2.77-3.15 Å, giving a μ6-binding mode. Two external Cl- ions adopt μ3-mode to cap the surface of the Ag14 cluster (Ag-Cl, 2.58-3.00 Å). The 10 cPrCC- ligands exhibit different coordination modes with mixed σ- and π-type bonding; 3 in μ4-ησ 1:ηπ 1:ηπ 1:ηπ 2; 5 in μ3-ησ 1:ησ 1:ηπ 2; 1 in μ3-ησ 1:ησ 1:ησ 1; 1 in μ3-ησ 1:ηπ 1:ηπ. The Ag-C distances range from 2.07 to 2.48 Å. The overall silver shell is also reinforced by Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag interactions ranging from 2.86 to 3.42 Å. These argentophilic interactions were also evidenced by the low-frequency bands in the solid-state Raman spectrum taken with laser excitation of λex = 632.8 nm (Figure S1). A moderate sharp peak located at 69.2 cm-1 was observed, which corresponds to the stretching vibration of the Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag bonds. The characteristic band for the CC stretching vibration was observed at ca. 2010 cm-1.

(b) Ball-and-stick view of each Cl@Ag14 cluster fused by three others. (c) The 3D cationic open framework viewed along the c-axis. The free p-TOS ions and water molecules were removed for clarity.

elements.content: More interesting, each Cl@Ag14 cluster fused with three neighbors at the silver trigonal or tetragonal faces through Ag–Cπ, Ag···Ag interaction, and Ag–Cl bonds rendering it a three-connected node (b). The extension of such nodes in three-dimensional space could give an overall 3D open framework (c). An important structural feature of compound SD/Ag14 is that it contains a three-periodic skeleton of silver atoms connected by Ag···Ag interactions and reinforced by organic ligands. The skeleton can be considered as formed from Cl@Ag14 clusters, whose centroids form an underlying net of the pcu-h topology with a Schläfli symbol of {6·102} (a). The pcu-h topology is three-coordinated, that is, each Ag14 cluster is adjacent to three other clusters (b,c), and it is a kind of decoration of the primitive cubic network (pcu) by hexagonal rings (d). The pcu-h topology is quite rare for coordination polymers according to the ToposPro TTO Collection. There are only eight pcu-h coordination networks, and none of them contains Ag atoms.

elements.content: When the reaction is performed in nonchlorinated solvent such as CH3(CH2)3OH, a one-dimensional silver–alkynyl coordination polymer, [Ag16(cPrCC)8(p-TOS)8(CH3(CH2)3OH)2·2­(CH3(CH2)3OH)] n (SD/Ag15), was obtained. X-ray crystallography revealed it crystallized in the triclinic P1̅ space group, and the asymmetric unit contains 16 Ag atoms, 8 cPrCC–, 8 p-TOS, 2 CH3(CH2)3OH, and 2 guest CH3(CH2)3OH (a). Among the 8 cPrCC– ligands, 4 are in μ4-ησ 1:η σ 1:ηπ 2:ηπ 2; 2 in μ4-ησ 1:ησ 1:ηπ 1:ηπ 2; 1 in μ4-ησ 1:ησ 1:ησ 1:ηπ 2; 1 in μ4-ησ 1:ησ 2:ηπ 2:ηπ. The Ag–C distances fall in the range 2.10–2.49 Å. Eight p-TOS ligands exhibited two different coordination modes with 3 adopting μ2-η1:η1 and 5 μ3-η1:η1:η1. Another two n-butanol ligands are anchored on the silver atoms through a Ag–O bond. The multidentate ligands aggregate the silver atoms extending nearly along the a-axis to from the resulting 1D chain structure (b), which is further consolidated by Ag···Ag interactions ranging from 2.81 to 3.39 Å. If all the organic ligands are removed, the resulting 1D silver backbone in SD/Ag15 is comprised of a silver-centered hexagon with two caps above and below and a pair of vertex-shared pentagon pyramids, which are alternatively arranged in the crystal lattice (c).

elements.content: Crystals of SD/Ag14 were dissolved in DMF (N,N′-dimethylformamide), and the solution behavior was investigated using high resolution electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (HRESI-MS). As shown in , a series of singly charged ion peaks in the m/z range of 2135–2440 were observed and assigned to species 1a–1g. Their formulas were identified based on the best agreement between the observed and simulated isotopic distribution patterns. The peak (1a) centered at m/z = 2150.1903 was assigned to [Ag12(cPrCC)9(p-TOS)­(Cl)­(C2H5OH)­(H2O)]+ (calcd m/z = 2150.2438). From 1b to 1f, they are assigned to different Ag13 species with the detailed formulas in the table in . The most abundant species in this family is 1d centered at m/z = 2282.1227. Only one peak corresponding to the parent cluster-based building unit at m/z = 2416.1544 was detected with the formula of [Ag14(cPrCC)8(p-TOS)­(OH)4(C2H5OH)2(H2O)3]+ (calcd. m/z = 2416.1203). These results clearly demonstrate that the 3D open framework does not remain intact but dissociated to other stable Ag12, Ag13, and Ag14 species in DMF. Combined with the solid-state structure analysis of SD/Ag14, we can speculate that Ag14 is the most possible building blocks for the construction of the silver cluster-based 3D open framework of SD/Ag14. The smaller Ag12 (1a) and Ag13 species (1b–1f) in solution should be generated from the dissociation of Ag14 and the association–dissociation equilibrium also existed between them. The exchange reaction between cyclopropylacetylene, water, Cl–, and OH– in solution were also observed between the species.

High Resolution Electrospray Ionization Mass Spectrometry (HRESI-MS)

Crystals of SD/Ag14 were dissolved in DMF (N,N'-dimethylformamide), and the solution behavior was investigated using high resolution electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (HRESI-MS). As shown in , a series of singly charged ion peaks in the m/z range of 2135-2440 were observed and assigned to species 1a-1g. Their formulas were identified based on the best agreement between the observed and simulated isotopic distribution patterns. The peak (1a) centered at m/z = 2150.1903 was assigned to [Ag12(cPrCC)9(p-TOS)(Cl)(C2H5OH)(H2O)]+ (calcd m/z = 2150.2438). From 1b to 1f, they are assigned to different Ag13 species with the detailed formulas in the table in . The most abundant species in this family is 1d centered at m/z = 2282.1227. Only one peak corresponding to the parent cluster-based building unit at m/z = 2416.1544 was detected with the formula of [Ag14(cPrCC)8(p-TOS)(OH)4(C2H5OH)2(H2O)3]+ (calcd. m/z = 2416.1203). These results clearly demonstrate that the 3D open framework does not remain intact but dissociated to other stable Ag12, Ag13, and Ag14 species in DMF. Combined with the solid-state structure analysis of SD/Ag14, we can speculate that Ag14 is the most possible building blocks for the construction of the silver cluster-based 3D open framework of SD/Ag14. The smaller Ag12 (1a) and Ag13 species (1b-1f) in solution should be generated from the dissociation of Ag14 and the association-dissociation equilibrium also existed between them. The exchange reaction between cyclopropylacetylene, water, Cl-, and OH- in solution were also observed between the species.

elements.content: For the colorless microcrystalline sample of SD/Ag15, there are no absorption bands in the visible region of its UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectrum (Figure S3), but strong absorptions are only in the UV region, mainly attributed to the π → π* transition of alkynyl group. Solid microcrystalline sample of SD/Ag14 is emission silent at room temperature, whereas SD/Ag15 emits blue luminescence centered at 442 nm with a shoulder peak at 468 nm () under the excitation of 345 nm (quantum yield 0.44%), which could be assigned to an admixture of an argentophilicity modified metal-centered state of Ag­(I) and ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) excited states. The luminescence transient decay is on the microsecond time scale at 293 K (τ1 = 1.52, τ2 = 4.17, and τ3 = 26.87 μs), suggesting the emission nature is phosphorescence with triplet excited state character (Figure S4).
elements.clean_text:
UV-Vis Absorption and Luminescent Properties of SD/Ag14 and SD/Ag15 

For the colorless microcrystalline sample of SD/Ag15, there are no absorption bands in the visible region of its UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectrum (Figure S3), but strong absorptions are only in the UV region, mainly attributed to the π → π* transition of alkynyl group. Solid microcrystalline sample of SD/Ag14 is emission silent at room temperature, whereas SD/Ag15 emits blue luminescence centered at 442 nm with a shoulder peak at 468 nm () under the excitation of 345 nm (quantum yield 0.44%), which could be assigned to an admixture of an argentophilicity modified metal-centered state of Ag(I) and ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) excited states. The luminescence transient decay is on the microsecond time scale at 293 K (τ1 = 1.52, τ2 = 4.17, and τ3 = 26.87 μs), suggesting the emission nature is phosphorescence with triplet excited state character (Figure S4).

elements.content: CrVI has long been recognized as a carcinogen and listed as a Group A human carcinogen by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). Many attempts benefiting from the growth of chemistry and material science have been made to capture and remove CrVI species from water. As a new generation of porous materials, metal–organic frameworks (MOF) have been preliminarily tested for the removal of CrVI species, but recognition of CrVI species trapped in MOFs and the mechanism of the adsorption are not well understand.
elements.clean_text:
Anion Exchange Properties of SD/Ag14 

CrVI has long been recognized as a carcinogen and listed as a Group A human carcinogen by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). Many attempts benefiting from the growth of chemistry and material science have been made to capture and remove CrVI species from water. As a new generation of porous materials, metal-organic frameworks (MOF) have been preliminarily tested for the removal of CrVI species, but recognition of CrVI species trapped in MOFs and the mechanism of the adsorption are not well understand.

elements.content: SD/Ag14 is a cationic framework with its channel filled by p-TOS anions that are weakly interacting with the 3D open framework (Figure S6). If the p-TOS is removed, a total empty volume is 8936.3 Å3, corresponding to 28.4% of the unit cell of SD/Ag14 as calculated by PLATON. Crystals of SD/Ag14 do not lose their crystallinity in water as proven by comparing the experimental and simulated patterns of the powder X-ray diffraction (Figure S7). Moreover, the single crystal X-ray data of SD/Ag14 can be still successfully collected and refined after immersion in water for 2 weeks. Based on these results, we sought to use such water-stable cationic framework to investigate the anion exchange between p-TOS and Cr2O7 2–, then render it as promising prototype adsorbent of CrVI from wastewater.

Based on these results, we sought to use such water-stable cationic framework to investigate the anion exchange between p-TOS and Cr2O7 2-, then render it as promising prototype adsorbent of CrVI from wastewater.

elements.content: We introduced 2.9 mg of SD/Ag14 into a 2 mL aqueous solution containing 0.176 mg of K2Cr2O7; then the anion exchange process was monitored by UV–vis spectroscopy to track the intensity variation of the characteristic absorption peak of Cr2O7 2– (257 nm) in water (a). The concentration of Cr2O7 2– in water diminished by 7.6%, 14.3%, and 18.3% after 0.5, 2, and 4 h, respectively, corresponding to capture capacities of 0.076, 0.143, and 0.183 mol mol–1. After 15 h, no more obvious changes were detected (b). After 48 h, the overall Cr2O7 2– loading capacity in SD/Ag14 is 0.3 mol mol–1, and the exchange percentage of p-TOS is 60%. In agreement, we also observed enhanced absorbance in the 190–300 nm range that corresponds to the simultaneously released p-TOS. The residual solution after anion exchange was also subjected to ESI-MS characterization (Figure S9), and the peak at m/z = 171.0231 corresponds to p-TOS (calcd m/z = 171.0121), which also proved that the p-TOS anions were released into the solution from SD/Ag14 by the exchange with Cr2O7 2– anions. When the amount of SD/Ag14 is changed from 2.9 to 5.9 or 14.7 mg, keeping the concentration of K2Cr2O7 (0.088 mg/mL) constant, we found that the K2Cr2O7 adsorption rate increased as shown by the slopes before reaching adsorption equilibrium (c).

The concentration of Cr2O7 2- in water diminished by 7.6%, 14.3%, and 18.3% after 0.5, 2, and 4 h, respectively, corresponding to capture capacities of 0.076, 0.143, and 0.183 mol mol-1. When the amount of SD/Ag14 is changed from 2.9 to 5.9 or 14.7 mg, keeping the concentration of K2Cr2O7 (0.088 mg/mL) constant, we found that the K2Cr2O7 adsorption rate increased as shown by the slopes before reaching adsorption equilibrium (c).

elements.content: During anion exchange, Cr2O7 2– is slowly converted to CrO4 2– in water as indicated by the shifted absorption band from 350 to 370 nm. Thus, there is a possibility that the AgI ion is slowly released from SD/Ag14 in water to form the insoluble Ag2CrO4 with CrO4 2–, which may be another reason for the concentration decrease of Cr2O7 2–. In order to rule out the formation of insoluble Ag2CrO4 during the anion exchange, we used inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analysis to quantitatively check the possible release of silver ions in the water (15 mg of SD/Ag14 immersed in 2 mL of water). The ICP results of three parallel experiments show that the supernatants give only trace of residual silver ions (average content 0.005%), which suggested that there is almost no AgI ion released in water; thus, the formation of Ag2CrO4 is negligible in the presence of CrO4 2– during the anion exchange process. This result also supported the high stability of SD/Ag14 in water.

elements.content: We also considered the selective exchange of Cr2O7 2– in the presence of other mixed anions such as SO4 2–, ClO4 –, and NO3 –. SD/SD14 was immersed into an aqueous mixture of K2Cr2O7 and salts of SO4 2–, ClO4 –, and NO3 – ions. The compared UV–vis absorbance (Figure S10) indicated the anion exchange efficiency between Cr2O7 2– and p-TOS is slightly disturbed by other contaminating anions.

elements.content: To further confirm anion exchange mode in the framework, we carefully selected a crystal after anion exchange (SD/Ag16) for 48 h for single-crystal X-ray diffraction experiment. Fortunately, the overall cationic framework of SD/Ag16 was clearly resolved and almost the same as SD/Ag14 but with the crystallographic c-axis and the unit cell volume doubled (Table S1). The energy-dispersive X-ray spectrum (EDX) mapping analysis (Figure S11) also proved the homogeneous distribution of Cr2O7 2– in SD/Ag16. These observations indicate that anion exchange happened through a single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation fashion. To our knowledge, the uptake of heavy metal pollutant anions by crystalline materials though the SC–SC transformation has rarely been reported; more importantly, SD/Ag14 is the first silver-cluster based open framework with uptake capability for Cr2O7 2–.

elements.content: The antibacterial performance of SD/Ag14 was studied because of its high stability in water and the existence of Ag ion. Staphylococcus aureus (S. aureus), a kind of Gram-positive bacteria, was chosen as a model, and a series of different concentrations of SD/Ag14 in the range of 0.1 to 10 μg/mL was tested for antibacterial activity. The insets in clearly show that the number of bacterial colonies grown on the plates is significantly reduced with the increase of SD/Ag14 concentration, indicating that the presence of SD/Ag14 can effectively inhibit the growth of S. aureus. The corresponding bacterial viability defined by the percentage of the colony number of treated bacteria compared to the colony number of control bacteria was calculated to quantitatively evaluate the antibacterial ability of SD/Ag14 at different concentrations. At 0.1 μg/mL, the viability of S. aureus is still 79.79%, and no significant difference (P > 0.05) between treated samples and control samples was observed by a statistical analysis, which means the concentration of added SD/Ag14 is too low to prevent S. aureus growth. As the concentration is increased to 1 μg/mL, the bacterial viability reduces to 49.10%, and then a considerable decrease occurs at 5 μg/mL, at which the viability of S. aureus is only 1.15%. When SD/Ag14 concentration is increased to 10 μg/mL, the growth of S. aureus is completely inhibited (). So SD/Ag14 has a strong antibacterial activity, especially at the concentration of ≥5 μg/mL. According to the findings of Lu et al., the excellent and long-term antibacterial activities of silver carboxylate MOF are attributed to the slow release of silver ions and the rupture of bacterial membrane caused by the silver-based MOF. Because SD/Ag14 is a kind of water-stable framework, the silver release would be relatively difficult and slow, which means SD/Ag14 is quite possible as a long-term antibacterial agent with synergistic contribution of controlled silver release. Further study on the antibacterial mechanism of SD/Ag14 will be designed in the future.
elements.clean_text:
Antibacterial Performance of SD/Ag14 

The antibacterial performance of SD/Ag14 was studied because of its high stability in water and the existence of Ag ion. Staphylococcus aureus (S. aureus), a kind of Gram-positive bacteria, was chosen as a model, and a series of different concentrations of SD/Ag14 in the range of 0.1 to 10 μg/mL was tested for antibacterial activity. The insets in  clearly show that the number of bacterial colonies grown on the plates is significantly reduced with the increase of SD/Ag14 concentration, indicating that the presence of SD/Ag14 can effectively inhibit the growth of S. aureus. The corresponding bacterial viability defined by the percentage of the colony number of treated bacteria compared to the colony number of control bacteria was calculated to quantitatively evaluate the antibacterial ability of SD/Ag14 at different concentrations. At 0.1 μg/mL, the viability of S. aureus is still 79.79%, and no significant difference (P > 0.05) between treated samples and control samples was observed by a statistical analysis, which means the concentration of added SD/Ag14 is too low to prevent S. aureus growth. As the concentration is increased to 1 μg/mL, the bacterial viability reduces to 49.10%, and then a considerable decrease occurs at 5 μg/mL, at which the viability of S. aureus is only 1.15%. When SD/Ag14 concentration is increased to 10 μg/mL, the growth of S. aureus is completely inhibited (). So SD/Ag14 has a strong antibacterial activity, especially at the concentration of ≥5 μg/mL. According to the findings of Lu et al., the excellent and long-term antibacterial activities of silver carboxylate MOF are attributed to the slow release of silver ions and the rupture of bacterial membrane caused by the silver-based MOF. Because SD/Ag14 is a kind of water-stable framework, the silver release would be relatively difficult and slow, which means SD/Ag14 is quite possible as a long-term antibacterial agent with synergistic contribution of controlled silver release. Further study on the antibacterial mechanism of SD/Ag14 will be designed in the future.

elements.content: In summary, we synthesized and characterized a novel water-stable 3D pcu-h metal–organic open framework, SD/Ag14, with a tetradecanuclear silver cluster as building block, and a 1D silver–alkynyl chain SD/Ag15 using solvent modulation strategy. The chloride plays a dual role by templating Ag14 and bridging the latter from the exterior to generate the 3D framework. Based on HRESI-MS, we also rationalized the Ag14 cluster as the building unit in solution before the formation of the final 3D framework, which authenticates a hierarchical cluster-based assembly. Such cationic framework can effectively absorb Cr2O7 2– through anion exchange in a single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation fashion. At a concentration of ≥5 μg/mL, the fabricated framework is highly efficient against S. aureus. Hence, this work not only enriched our knowledge of the silver-cluster based 3D open framework including its novel structure and assembly mechanism but also preliminarily justified the plausibility of such silver-cluster based framework for the Cr2O7 2– trapping from water and bacterial inhibition.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we synthesized and characterized a novel water-stable 3D pcu-h metal-organic open framework, SD/Ag14, with a tetradecanuclear silver cluster as building block, and a 1D silver-alkynyl chain SD/Ag15 using solvent modulation strategy. The chloride plays a dual role by templating Ag14 and bridging the latter from the exterior to generate the 3D framework. Based on HRESI-MS, we also rationalized the Ag14 cluster as the building unit in solution before the formation of the final 3D framework, which authenticates a hierarchical cluster-based assembly. Such cationic framework can effectively absorb Cr2O7 2- through anion exchange in a single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation fashion. At a concentration of ≥5 μg/mL, the fabricated framework is highly efficient against S. aureus. Hence, this work not only enriched our knowledge of the silver-cluster based 3D open framework including its novel structure and assembly mechanism but also preliminarily justified the plausibility of such silver-cluster based framework for the Cr2O7 2- trapping from water and bacterial inhibition.

cln_elements.content:
Ethynylcyclopropane (24 mmol, 2 mL) in ethanol (15 mL) was added to Ag2O (13 mmol, 3 g) in ammonia solution (60 mL). The mixture was stirred for 1 h, and the white precipitate (3.9 g, 93.3%) was collected by sucking filtration, then washed with EtOH and Et2O.

Synthesis of <bold>SD/Ag14</bold> and <bold>SD/Ag16</bold>

[cPrCCAg] n (0.1 mmol, 17.4 mg), NaCl (0.11 mmol, 6.5 mg), and p-TOSAg (0.1 mmol, 27.9 mg) were dissolved in distilled EtOH (5 mL) in the presence of 10 μL of tetramethylethylenediamine (TMEDA); the resulting solution was treated by sonication for 20 min at room temperature to give a turbid solution, which was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and kept at 60 °C for 1200 min and then slowly cooled to room temperature (). The colorless filtrate was left to stand in the dark at room temperature. After one month, colorless crystals were deposited with a yield of 25%. When p-TOSAg was replaced by p-TOSH in the presence of 40 μL of TMEDA, colorless crystals of SD/Ag14 were obtained with an optimized yield of 50% after 1 week. Anal. for C171H173Ag42Cl9S3O10 (SD/Ag14), calcd (found): C, 28.00 (28.02); H, 2.38 (2.37) %. IR: 3668 (w), 2973 (s), 2903 (s), 1398 (m), 1240 (w), 1072 (s), 887 (w) cm–1. The colorless crystals of SD/Ag14 were immersed in an aqueous solution of K2Cr2O7 (0.08 mg mL–1) for 48 h to give orange crystals of SD/Ag16.

Synthesis of <bold>SD/Ag15</bold>

The compound SD/Ag15 was prepared by solvothermal reaction as follows: [cPrCCAg] n (0.1 mmol, 17.4 mg), p-TOSAg (0.1 mmol, 27.9 mg), and CH3(CH2)3OH (5 mL) were mixed together and then sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and kept at 60 °C for 1200 min. After cooling to room temperature, the colorless crystals were collected in 40% yield. Anal. for C112H136Ag16S8O28 (SD/Ag15), calcd (found): C, 34.38 (34.35); H, 2.35 (2.36) %. IR: 3387 (w), 2989 (w), 2003 (m), 1640 (w), 1595­(w), 1487 (w), 1161 (s), 1116 (s), 1016 (s), 944 (m), 816 (m), 681 (m), 572 (s) cm–1.

cln_elements.content: For the colorless microcrystalline sample of SD/Ag15, there are no absorption bands in the visible region of its UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectrum (Figure S3), but strong absorptions are only in the UV region, mainly attributed to the π → π* transition of alkynyl group. Solid microcrystalline sample of SD/Ag14 is emission silent at room temperature, whereas SD/Ag15 emits blue luminescence centered at 442 nm with a shoulder peak at 468 nm () under the excitation of 345 nm (quantum yield 0.44%), which could be assigned to an admixture of an argentophilicity modified metal-centered state of Ag­(I) and ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) excited states. The luminescence transient decay is on the microsecond time scale at 293 K (τ1 = 1.52, τ2 = 4.17, and τ3 = 26.87 μs), suggesting the emission nature is phosphorescence with triplet excited state character (Figure S4).
cln_elements.clean_text:
UV-Vis Absorption and Luminescent Properties of SD/Ag14 and SD/Ag15 

For the colorless microcrystalline sample of SD/Ag15, there are no absorption bands in the visible region of its UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectrum (Figure S3), but strong absorptions are only in the UV region, mainly attributed to the π → π* transition of alkynyl group. Solid microcrystalline sample of SD/Ag14 is emission silent at room temperature, whereas SD/Ag15 emits blue luminescence centered at 442 nm with a shoulder peak at 468 nm () under the excitation of 345 nm (quantum yield 0.44%), which could be assigned to an admixture of an argentophilicity modified metal-centered state of Ag(I) and ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) excited states. The luminescence transient decay is on the microsecond time scale at 293 K (τ1 = 1.52, τ2 = 4.17, and τ3 = 26.87 μs), suggesting the emission nature is phosphorescence with triplet excited state character (Figure S4).

peak spectrum.condition: excitation of 345 nm, quantum yield 0.44%, temperature 293 K

cln_elements.content: (a) The simplified 3D open framework with a pcu-h topology (Schläfli symbol {6·102}) with the red and cyan rings representing the six- and ten-membered rings. (b) Skeleton of silver atoms (gray balls) in the crystal structure of SD/Ag14. The red lines show the underlying net of the pcu-h topology. Thick gray lines join the centroid of two Ag14 clusters forming the underlying net. (c) Ag14 cluster shown by balls and cylinders and three groups of adjacent silver atoms from other Ag14 clusters in the skeleton. (d) Relation between pcu (blue balls) and pcu-h (red lines) topologies.
